titleStmt.title: An Accrostick Sonnet. To his worthy and deerly beloved friend the AVTHORPag. 8. lin. 7. for laughing, reade, languishing.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: An Accrostick Sonnet. To his worthy and deerly beloved friend the AVTHORPag. 8. lin. 7. for laughing, reade, languishing.

monogr.title: A sixth booke to the Countesse of Pembrokes Arcadia. VVritten by R.B. esq
monogr.author: Bellings, Richard

div.head: An Accrostick Sonnet. To his worthy and deerly beloved friend the AVTHORPag. 8. lin. 7. for laughing, reade, languishing.
div.l: Rather to show my love, then sing thy praise,
I write these lines; for what is knowne to me,
Cannot (my Belling) s • and within my layes,
Having lesse words then what to speake of thee:
And 〈◊〉 thy worth for want of words or phrase
Refin'd and quaint, want due applause, or be
Drencht in oblivion? no, the • acred Bayes
Begirts thy head, as a deserved see.
Enough, that speakes thee; for on worthlesse browes
Long tress'd Apollo ne're bestowes his bowes.
Live happy then, and sor thy Countries blisse
I wish thou mayst live long: thy Workes renowne thee,
No better steps thou couldst have tract then His.
Go on, and time, with Sidney's fame, shall crowne Thee.
